1.title: Unknown Lady
1.sitter_text: Unknown Lady (perhaps of the Vavasour family)
1.description_content: Isaac Oliver's portrait of a fashionably attired unknown lady depicts a young, stylishly attired woman, with a black hat and a profusion of white lace and pearls. She has long been considered a ‘typical’ example of this artist's work.
1.description_physical:
The ultraviolet (UV) image of this work shows that numerous areas have been retouched. These include portions of her hat and black costume, which display a greenish fluorescence under UV illumination, indicative of the presence of modern pigments, such as zinc white (as confirmed by additional X-ray fluorescence [XRF] analysis). Extensive repainting can also be identified throughout the white passages of the costume.

The white overpainting appears to be covering dull grey (original) paint, whose muted colour must have been the reason for the extensive intervention. This grey pigment has been identified as calomel, which was probably white initially, but exposure to light or possibly alkali turned it grey, thus making necessary the extensive repainting.
1.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, vermilion, bone black (retouching), zinc white (retouching), indigo (retouching); lace: calomel/mercury white (retouch: barium sulphate); ruff:  barium sulphate (retouching), calcium-based compound (retouching)
1.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, vermilion, red lead; lips: red lead, vermilion, pink lake
1.pigments_hair_and_beard: Carbon-based black, red lead, lead white, yellow earth pigments

28.title: Ludovick Stuart, 2nd Duke of Lennox and Duke of Richmond 1574-1624
28.sitter_text: Ludovick Stuart, 2nd Duke of Lennox and Duke of Richmond
28.description_physical:
Inscription on the verso written in a 19th century hand: 'Rt Devereux Earl of Essex / by Isaac Oliver'.

Two different shapes of the collar are evident in the MA-XRF lead (Pb-LA map) and calcium maps, X-ray image and NIR image, with the initial, lower collar being repainted and replaced by an upper collar. The raking light image and the micrographs show how brittle is the lead white paint passage of the proper right collar, painted over the azurite background. The blue background and upper part of the ribbon were repainted in ultramarine.

29.title: Unknown Man
29.description_content:
Inscription in gold left of the head reads 'Anno Domini 1588'.
Inscription in gold right of the head reads 'AE Suae 57'.
Inscription on the verso of the portrait reads '1588 Miniature'.
29.description_physical:
The miniature is in a good state of preservation, and only localised retouching is evident in the zinc MA-XRF map, showing that the modern zinc white pigment was used to retouch small areas. 
The UV image shows the pale orange fluorescence of lead white in the ruff area, and a more pinkish fluorescence is evident on the lips and cheeks, likely associated to the use of an organic dye. 
The mercury MA-XRF map shows that the modelling of the flesh tones is achieved with an extensive use of vermilion.

30.title: Unknown Lady
30.description_physical:
The elaborate black dress and hat contain two black pigments (carbon black and bone black) and lead white to achieve the grey tone. Vermilion is mixed with bone black in the sleeves only, and lead-tin yellow is found in the darkest areas of the corset. 
The miniature is extensively retouched in the face and background, as evidenced by raking light (retouched areas appearing raised), UV (retouching of bright yellowish colour on face, background, ruff and shirt), and X-ray image (the lighter areas in the face corresponding to the use of another pigment on top of the original lead white, and the darker ones in the background corresponding to colour loss). The zinc distribution MA-XRF map identifies zinc white as the modern white pigment used, while the cobalt distribution map highlights the use of cerulean blue (in combination with tin) and smalt (in combination with potassium and nickel).
A round shape on the dress is evident in the iron and manganese distribution maps, possibly associated with retouching.
30.pigments_background: Azurite, cobalt blue (retouching), cerulean blue (retouching), zinc white (retouching)
30.pigments_costume: Dress/hat: bone black, lead white, indigo, ultramarine, vermilion (sleeves), lead-tin yellow, carbon-based black (retouching), zinc white (retouching); ruff: lead white, indigo (+ ultramarine and azurite for shading), zinc white (retouching)

49.title: A lady (b. c. 1567)
49.description_content: This miniature shows a lady wearing a capotain hat with a rounded crown and her right hand placed on her hip. She is depicted in a three-quarter length format--an unusual format for portrait miniatures that tend to show sitters in half-length or bust-length formats. It is one of the earliest known attributable to Isaac Oliver, with an inscription in gold that reads 'Anno Domini 1587, aetatis suae 20'. While the costume is 'just' black, Oliver put great care into the modelling, using two different blacks to achieve subtle differences in hue and saturation by mixing in tiny amounts of lead-tin yellow, lead white and small, and he has used tiny shell-silver dots (now tarnished to black) to detail the hat brim and the zigzag pattern on the hat ribbon, which can still be seen in the micrograph detail of the hat.
49.description_physical:
The UV image shows retouching evident in the flesh tones, white shirt and ruff. It appears of greenish colour under UV light and is associated with the use of zinc white.  
The palette identified is consistent with the materials employed by Isaac Oliver. However, the use of smalt and lead-tin yellow in different parts of the black dress and a lead-tin yellow base layer under gilding is unusual.
The original back of the miniature was not accessible, but a vermilion detail, probably a seal, is evident in the MA-XRF-generated mercury distribution map and in the x-ray. The x-ray also shows that the positioning of the proper right hand may have been altered, moving the hand further back than initially planned.
49.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, lead-tin yellow, smalt; ruff: lead white (retouch: zinc white); pink ribbon: lead white, pink lake
49.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead (retouch: zinc white); lips: red lake
49.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead white, carbon black
49.pigments_jewellery: Gold (yellow layer underneath: lead-tin yellow type I)

50.title: A lady, called Frances Walsingham, Countess of Essex (b.1550)
50.sitter_text: A lady, called Frances Walsingham, Countess of Essex
50.description_content: A young woman depicted in a highly elaborate costume and standing ruff with extensive lace-detailing. The white dress and lace were set off with copious strokes of shell-silver to indicate highlights on pearls and jewels, but also imitating silver-thread embroidery on the bodice, which has now tarnished to black. While the miniature is highly worked and would have initially glittered when held and moved as a result of the shell silver applications catching the light, it has an otherwise restrained palette that would have set off the very fair complexion of the sitter.
50.description_physical:
The dark grey background painted with bone black and possibly an organic dye is an unusual choice among the Isaac Oliver's miniatures analysed.
The UV image clearly shows retouching in the flesh tones and the background and outlining of the white detailing in the dress; the bright UV fluorescence indicates the use of zinc white for the extensive retouching. The miniature has suffered from the loss of many of its silver highlights on pearls and jewellery, and of the bodied daubs of lead white siting beneath. The best preserved shell silver passage is the star-shaped pendant, where the silver sits on top of gold. Mercury, possibly in the form of quicksilver, occurs simultaneously with the silver and could suggest the use of an amalgam.
50.pigments_costume: Dress: lead white (zinc white for retouching); ruff: lead white, indigo (for shading)
50.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead; lips: red lead, vermilion, red dye
50.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead white, umber pigment (dark passages)

51.title: A lady, called Lady Arabella Stuart (1575-1615)
51.sitter_text: A lady, called Lady Arabella Stuart (1575-1615)
51.description_content: A well-preserved portrait of a young female sitter with her long, curly hair hanging loose behind her shoulders. She is wearing an embroidered  bodice with low décolletage, a pearl and gold earring, a pearl choker with a large diamond and pearl-studded gold pendant suspended from a black string, and a long, black string necklace disappearing behind the lace-edged trim of the bodice. Her costume bears a strong resemblance with those worn by several female sitters by portrait painter William Larkin (active 1609-19) and his followers, such as Isabella Rich, Mrs. Rogers (1614-18), Jane, Lady Thornaugh (1617) and portraits of Frances Howard, Duchess of Richmond and Lennox.
51.description_physical:
The miniatures appears to be in a good state of preservation. Under UV light, no retouching is evident. 
Some features and material choices are unusual when compared to other Oliver miniatures. For instance, the white lace containing lead-tin yellow to achieve a warmer tone when painted over the dress, in contrast to the pure lead white lace painted over the flesh tones. The warm yellow base of the pendant contains lead-tin yellow with further reddish-brown detailing, which is also uncommon for Oliver. The presence of copper chlorides identified in the greens has never been identified in other Oliver's miniatures.
51.pigments_costume: Lead white, azurite (blue flowers), red lead (orange flowers), red lake (pink flowers), lead tin yellow and copper chlorides (green flowers), lead tin yellow type I (yellow flowers), organic green? (dark green stem); ruff: lead white, lead tin yellow
51.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, chalk; lips: red lead, red lake
51.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, lead white, gypsum, lead tin yellow

52.title: John Donne (1573-1631)
52.description_content: This miniature of John Donne is likely to be a copy after the version in the Royal Collection (RCIN 420026), also featured on this website.
52.description_physical:
The miniature has been retouched with smalt in the background and zinc white in the collar. This could indicate two different campaigns of intervention.
Technically, in comparison with the version in the Royal Collection (RCIN 420026), it is executed quite differently. It lacks the controlled stippling technique and the precise modelling of the original. Materially, there is a great deal of overlaps with RCIN 420026, however vermilion, used in the lips, is only present in this version and appears not to have been part of the palette of RCIN 420026.
52.pigments_costume: Doublet: carbon black,earth pigment, copper-based pigment, lead white (for highlights); ruff: lead white, copper-based pigment (shading)

53.title: A young girl
53.artist_text: Issac Oliver; later additions by Unknown
53.description_content:
This miniature has either been left unfinished, or was intended as a studio pattern deliberately done in a sketchy fashion (other surviving versions are not known). The heavy dark outlines of the hair-ornaments, the cursory yet informative setting out of the dress features, and the lack of modelling to the face, may indicate the latter, as finished miniatures would not typically feature the relatively heavy-handed daubs and black outlining at the early stages of execution, since these would be difficult to disguise later on in the painting process using gum-bound pigments on vellum. 

It has been embellished at a later point, in particular with reinforcements to the figure-of-eight lines of the collar drawn up with zinc white, pointing to a C19th or C20th intervention.
53.description_physical: The UV image shows pink UV fluorescence in the background, corresponding to the use of a red organic dye, and a pale orange fluorescence on the ruff and dress indicate  the presence of lead white. Some zinc-based retouching, appearing bright green under UV light, is evident on the ruff. Silver, now tarnished to black, was used for the black line pattern on the sleeve.
53.pigments_costume: Dress: lead white, carbon black (shading), azurite (blue detailing); ruff: lead white, copper-based pigment, zinc white (retouch), cobalt blue (retouch); headdress: azurite, yellow ochre
53.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white; lips: red organic dye

54.title: Thomas, 3rd and last Viscount Howard of Bindon (d.1610)
54.sitter_text: Thomas, 3rd and last Viscount Howard of Bindon
54.description_content: While technically different to Isaac Oliver's miniatures, the purple background situates this miniature in the 17th century when this colour was introduced for portrait miniature backgrounds.
54.description_physical: The pigment selection found in this miniature are wholly consistent with those available in the period of Isaac Oliver's active years, with the exception of the inscription in the background, which appears to be  brass-based, and was not used by Oliver.

56.title: Jane Boughton, née Coningsby (b. 1553)
56.description_content: The support for this early miniature by Hilliard is still visible. It shows a section of the dress of a Queen of Clubs (upside down) and is of the standard Rouen design common in England at the time of the miniature's creation.
56.description_physical:
The identified pigment palette of this miniature is compatible with the materials available to Hilliard.
UV image: the flesh tone appears bright white, due to the fluorescence of the parchment underneath; the orange UV fluorescence colour is associated to the use of lead white. 
The verso of the playing card was analysed: red areas: vermilion; dark and blue areas: indigo; green area: indigo and likely a yellow dye; yellow areas: yellow dye(?); purple areas: red/ purple dye(?)

56.pigments_jewellery: Silver; gold (orange underlayer: earth pigments and arsenic sulphides)

57.title: Unknown Woman, formerly called Anne, Lady Hundson (c. 1529–1607)
57.sitter_text: Unknown Woman, formerly called Anne, Lady Hunsdon (c. 1529–1607)
57.description_content:
The sitter's complexion in this finely detailed portrait is unusually dark for Hilliard's palette, and the (Fe) MA-XRF map shows that this is likely caused by the unusual presence of earth pigment in the carnation.
The playing card back of this Hilliard miniature was not accessible for the analysis, but the mercury (Hg) MA-XRF map shows the presence of a single heart, at a sideways orientation, made of vermilion.
57.description_physical:
The UV image shows that this miniature is in a good state of preservation. The pale orange UV fluorescence colour (for instance evident on the ruff) is due to the presence of lead white.

Silver has been detected in the pupils, presumably used to indicate a reflection of light, and gold and silver have been used extensively for the delicate ornamentation of the dress.
57.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, zinc white (retouching); blue gem: ultramarine blue; red enamelled figures: red lead; white ruff: lead white, carbon black (shading), barium sulphate (retouching)

57.pigments_hair_and_beard: Yellow earth pigment, lead tin yellow, lead white(?), carbon black
57.pigments_jewellery: Gold (yellow underlayer: lead tin yellow type I, lead white, arsenic sulphides); silver

58.title: Unknown Man, formerly called Edward, Baron Herbert of Cherbury
58.sitter_text: Unknown Man, formerly called Edward, Baron Herbert of Cherbury
58.description_content: The yellow tone of the lace in this miniature, achieved with lead-tin yellow, is unusual, however the micrograph images show how the pale yellow paint is added on top of an existing lace pattern in white. It is notable, on comparison with other Oliver miniatures, that the quality (in terms of the consistency and precision of the paint handling) of the execution of the lace in this miniature is less accomplished than other examples more securely attributed to Oliver.
58.description_physical:
UV and NIR images show retouched areas in the background, which appear light blue and light grey, respectively. 
The monogram is painted on a retouched area, but the gold (Au) MA-XRF map shows the presence of a monogram (likely original) present underneath.

The pigment palette is consistent with Oliver’s materials and technique, especially regarding the mixtures for the flesh tones and hair. Lips contain vermilion, which is usually not identified after 1610.
58.pigments_background: Azurite (retouched with zinc white, cobalt blue, cerulean blue)
58.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; ruff: lead white and carbon black (grey lower layer), lead white (lace), lead tin yellow (yellow lace)
58.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, chalk, red lead(?); lips: vermilion, red lead(?), red lake
58.pigments_hair_and_beard: Yellow earth pigments, lead white, lead tin yellow, carbon black(?)

59.title: Portrait of a Lady
59.description_content: This portrait of a Lady is smaller than the average miniature by Oliver, however the assured execution and fine detailing does not give this fact away. It is in very good condition despite the moderate fading and the consistent tarnishing of the silver used for the highlight on the pearls and the jewels on the pendant, and only small retouched areas are evident around the border and in the hair (see raking light and UV images).
59.description_physical:
The orange UV fluorescence in the lace, pearls and eyes is due to the use of lead white. A pink UV fluorescence in the lips suggests the presence of organic dyes.

The mercury MA-XRF map highlights the use of vermilion to outline the hair of the sitter. Mercury is also associated with the silver, as evident in the pearls and pendant in the (HG) MA-XRF map.
59.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black; white ruff: lead white, indigo used for shading
59.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead; lips: pink lake
59.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead white, carbon black

60.title: Portrait of a Lady
60.description_content: This miniature by Jacob Van der Doordt, who was influenced by English miniature painting, serves as an interesting comparison with Isaac Oliver's. The hatching technique used to model the face is more evident than in Oliver's works and is particularly visible in UV.  The x-ray and (Pb) MA-XRF map show a thicker application of lead white for the carnation, which appears white against the surroundings, while Oliver's carnations rely on the vellum to give a pale hue and they are therefore typically dark in x-ray because little x-ray opaque pigment is present. That van der Doordt added more actual pigment may perhaps be explained by the fact that he was also active as a painter in oils.
60.description_physical:
The miniature is in a good state of preservation, with no evident retouching in the UV or NIR images.
Lead (Pb) MA-XRF map shows a possible alteration in the proper left sleeve, which also contains a high amount of zinc.
60.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, chalk, lead white; ruff: lead white, vermilion (red lace); leaves on the headdress: lead tin yellow, red lead, organic green(?)
60.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, unidentified red pigment, drying oil(?); lips: red lead, red lake
60.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, lead white/ red lead, vermilion, lead tin yellow, carbon black(?)
60.Credit: The Thomson Collection at the Art Gallery of Ontario

61.title: Portrait of a Lady
61.description_content: This highly accomplished miniature by Hilliard shows a woman fashionably dressed in a black dress with extensive detailing painstakingly rendered and an early example of a Tudor capotain hat more common from  1590 onwards.
61.description_physical:
A few retouched areas are evident around the border. The lighter grey areas in the NIR images at the top and bottom of the miniature, corresponding to the darker regions of the X-ray image, suggest a localised loss of the pictorial layer and the use of blue and green pigments different from the original ones to make good the losses.  
The UV image reveals additional retouching in the black dress of the sitter, which displays a bright green UV fluorescence characteristic of zinc compounds.
Two retouching campaigns are evident based on the use of white pigments: the sitter's dress and the joint line along the top are retouched with zinc white, whereas the blue top and green bottom are retouched using titanium white. 
The heart of the playing card is painted with vermilion.
61.pigments_background: Azurite, ultramarine blue (retouching), titanium white (rutile(?) (retouching); green foreground: copper sulphate (antlerite), chrome green (retouching)
61.pigments_costume: Dress: bone black, lead white, zinc white (retouching); ruff and shirt: lead white, carbon black (shading)
61.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), vermilion(?); lips: vermilion, pink lake

62.title: Portrait of a Gentleman
62.description_content: This miniature portrait, likely painted after c.1630 by John Hoskins (1590/95-1664/65), has likely suffered from a significant degree of fading that has affected the carnation in particular. It is likely that fugitive lakes were employed to model this passage, which have lost their colour. The result is that the face is now characterised by very strong contrasts and lacks smooth transitions between light and shade.
62.description_physical:
The miniature is in a good state of preservation. 
The UV image shows an orange UV colour on the flesh tone, suggesting the use of lead white. 

The lead (Pb) and calcium (Ca) MA-XRF maps show a possible change in the shape of the hat.
Calcium, likely as chalk, is used to paint the base layer of the ruff, whereas the lace is painted with lead white, and is also used to modulate the bone black of the doublet.
62.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; ruff: chalk, lead white (lace)
62.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, earth pigments; lips: red lead

63.title: Portrait of William Drummond of Hawthornden (c. 1615)
63.description_content: This miniature is no longer believed to be the poet William Drummond of Hawthornden (1585-1649).
63.description_physical:
The UV image shows localised retouching on the white ruff and flesh areas: the retouching appears bright yellow in UV which is usually associated with the presence of zinc white. The dull orange UV fluorescence colour evident on the ruff is instead due to the use of lead white, and is original. A dark red/maroon UV fluorescence colour on the background is likely due to the use of a red lake and indigo to achieve purple.

The x-ray image highlights the wood grain of the support onto which the miniature is laid. 
This image is also particularly useful in this case because it reveals the presence of an upside-down heart  in the area of the sitter's face. This symbol is present on the playing card, the back of which remains inaccessible due to the framing of this object. The (Hg) MA-XRF map suggests that this heart was executed using vermilion.
63.pigments_costume: Doublet: bone black, carbon black, lead white; white ruff: lead white, azurite (shading), zinc white (retouching)
63.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, chalk, red lead(?), earth pigment(?), barium white (retouching); lips: red lake, red lead(?)
63.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth and umber pigments, chalk, lead-based pigment, lead-tin yellow, carbon black(?)

64.title: Portrait of Henry Stewart, Lord Darnley,                                                                 second consort of Mary, Queen of Scots
64.sitter_text: Portrait of Henry Stewart, Lord Darnley, second consort of Mary, Queen of Scots
64.description_content: An early miniature pre-dating Hilliard and Oliver. However, the inscription may be only partly original, while a slightly later calligrapher appears to have added 'Aetatis Sua : 18' using a scrolling font more akin to Hilliard's. Henry Stuart would have been 14 years old in 1560, which is the date inscribed, in a different font, along the upper left edge.
64.description_physical:
The miniature is in a good state of preservation. The UV image shows the presence of some losses in the pictorial layer, which result in bright white areas corresponding to the parchment underneath. The two small areas on the flesh tone with a bright fluorescence are caused by a retouching made with zinc white. 

The mercury (Hg) map shows considerable amount of vermilion used for outlining facial features and in the lips and hair.
The barium (Ba) in the background is likely to be an impurity of azurite.
64.pigments_costume: Doublet: lead tin yellow type I, red earth
64.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, chalk, vermilion; lips: vermilion
64.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, chalk, lead tin yellow, lead white, vermilion, red lead(?), carbon black

65.title: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
65.sitter_text: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
65.description_content: This otherwise well-preserved miniature has suffered damage in the face that appears deliberate, targeting the cheeks, nose ridge and forehead. These passages appear to have been lightly scraped, most visibly in the raking light image. It is unclear what prompted this intervention.
65.description_physical:
The raking light image shows the floating-in technique used to paint the background around the sitter's outline. Under UV, the miniature seems to be in a good state of preservation, with some colour losses around the border, which appear bright white due to the fluorescence of the parchment. The orange UV fluorescence displayed by the collar suggests the use of lead white in this area, whereas the pinkish colour of the lips indicates the presence of a red organic dye.
The blue background appears dark in the NIR image, due to the use of a copper-based pigment (azurite), as well as the black doublet and hat due to the presence of carbon-based black pigments. A faint hatching is evident around the border of the background, likely made with a different blue pigment.
The flesh tones are painted with only a small amount of lead white, as evident in the x-ray image because they appear dark. The doublet and hat also appear dark, but the modelling and detailing of the doublet by employing a little lead white is evident in the doublet.
65.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; white collar: lead white, azurite; black hat: bone black, carbon black
65.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), vermilion (for outlining the features); lips: red lead(?)
65.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, carbon black(?), lead white(?)

66.title: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
66.sitter_text: George Clifford (1558-1605), 3rd Earl of Cumberland, Admiral
66.description_content: The state of preservation of this miniature is generally good, with the exception of damage around the edges in the background prompting later retouching.
66.description_physical:
The raking light shows the floating-in technique for the background, applied around the sitter's head and beard. Some colour losses are evident around the border. 
Under UV, the collar, costume and small details in the eyes show a bright red UV fluorescence, characteristic of mercury white. The miniature appears retouched around the border, especially at the top and left edges, and in the area of the sash; the bright yellow-green UV fluorescence of the retouching suggests the use of zinc white.
Blue and green areas appear dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments. In particular, the retouched areas in the blue background are distinguishable from the original paint passage because the appear slightly darker.
The flesh tones are painted using very little lead white, as evident from the x-ray image where the dark area corresponds to flesh tones and hair. A heavy element, identified by XRF as mercury, is used in the costume, collar and eyes. These passages appear white.
66.pigments_costume: Doublet: lead white, calomel/mercury white; blue flowers: azurite; orange flowers: red lead; pink flowers: red lake; green leaves: mineral copper green, yellow dye(?); deep blue sash: azurite, red organic dye; collar: lead white, calomel/mercury white
66.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, vermilion; lips: red lead(?)
66.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigment, calomel/vermilion, lead-based pigment, carbon black(?)

67.title: A lady, formerly called Catherine, Countess of Suffolk (1566 - 1633)
67.sitter_text: A lady, formerly called Catherine, Countess of Suffolk (1566 - 1633)
67.description_content:
A particularly fine example of Isaac Oliver's work.
'Infelix Spectator' written in gold on the background.
67.description_physical:
The palette identified is consistent with the materials and techniques employed by Oliver.
The UV image shows retouched areas on the ruff: they appear greenish due to the use of zinc white and in contrast to the pale orange UV fluorescence colour given by lead white, employed by the artist. Parts of the background, especially around the edges, are also retouched, as they appear greenish or blue in comparison with the azurite background, which quenches the UV light.

71.title: Portrait of a young woman, called Mrs Cam of Newport, Gloucestershire
71.description_content:
A very finely executed miniature. The face has suffered from fading, and the execution of the lips is uncharacteristically clumsy. This may be explained by the possible later reinforcement of the lips, due to the loss of original colour in this passage. 
The pearls and jewels have on some cases lost their silver highlights, which have pulled away the underlying lead white or orange-brown underlayers respectively. In the pendant, the losses reveal fine red lines, which indicated the shape and positioning of the jewels.
71.description_physical: UV image: a loss of colour is evident in the lower part of the miniature, which appears bright white under UV light, possibly due to the fluorescence of the parchment support. An orange UV colour is instead typical of lead white and evident in the dress. Other retouched areas are present in the background, towards the top and right edges.

75.title: Henry, Prince of Wales
75.description_physical:
Lead tin yellow is unusually used for modelling in the neck and forehead. 
The UV image shows an intense fluorescence in the flesh tones, due to the parchment emerging through the thin layers of pigments, and a pink fluorescence in the red toga, which comes from the use of organic dyes.
The raking light image shows some swelling on the forehead and chin of the sitter, and possibly in the background at the proper left side. Losses of pigment are evident in the red toga, where the parchment can be seen.
The blue portion of the breastplate appears dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of azurite. Red pigments are transparent to the IR radiation, therefore the toga and lips do not appear in the NIR image.
The x-ray radiography do not show a particular preparatory layer for the sitter's figure, which appears of the same level of grey of the background.The white highlights on the toga and the metal-based detailing are evident in the image, showing the presence of elements like lead, silver and gold.
75.pigments_costume: Red toga: red lead, lead white, red organic dye(?); blue breastplate: azurite, lead white; brown breastplate: earth pigment (goethite), lead white
75.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, lead tin yellow, red lead(?), chalk; lips: pink lake
75.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, chalk, carbon black, lead tin yellow, lead white(?)

76.title: Richard Boyle, 1st Earl of Cork
76.description_physical:
The collar of the sitter has been repainted, as evident in the lead MA-XRF map and x-ray image. A previous version showed a standing collar with lace covering the surface. This may due to a pentimento of the artist. 
The slashes of the doublet seems to be originally painted with azurite, as shown in the copper MA-XRF map, and later retouched with smalt. The blue colour of this detailing is unusual. 
Several retouching in different campaigns are evident in the blue background, including ultramarine blue, smalt and Prussian blue, likely following a water damage all around the border. In the NIR image, the dark portions of the background are likely due to the use of azurite, whereas the other pigments used for the retouching are transparent to the IR radiation and therefore, they disappear or appear only moderately grey.
The UV image shows the typical orange UV colour of lead white in the collar, some pink fluorescence in the flesh tones and lips due to the use of organic dyes, and a bright spot in the background due to the presence of zinc white.
76.pigments_background: Azurite, ultramarine blue (retouching), Prussian blue (retouching), smalt (retouching), zinc white (retouching), titanium white (retouching), barium white (retouching)
76.pigments_costume: Doublet: carbon black, bone black, lead white; slashes: azurite, smalt (retouching), red lead; ruff: lead white, indigo (shading)
76.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, vermilion, chalk; lips: red lead, vermilion, red organic dye
76.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth and umber pigments, carbon black, bone black, lead tin yellow(?), lead white(?), vermilion (on the beard only)

77.title: Ludovick Stuart, 2nd Duke of Lennox and Duke of Richmond
77.sitter_text: Ludovick Stuart, 2nd Duke of Lennox and Duke of Richmond
77.description_physical:
A water damage affected this miniature, resulting in a repainting of the background and hair. It is not clear if an alteration of the shape of the hair occurred.

Based on the MA-XRF copper map, the original azurite background is preserved only in the area surrounding the proper right side of the sitter's face. The rest of it has been repainted with ultramarine (evident in the NIR image, where the background disappears to the IR radiation), likely following the water damage. 
Retouching in the background and ribbon are evident in the raking light image, where the surface texture does not appear uniform, and the UV image. In the latter, the bright fluorescence documented in the background and collar indicate the use of zinc white. The flesh tones also appear bright under UV light, due to the parchment showing though the thin layers of pigments.

77.pigments_costume: Doublet: bone black, lead white; ruff: lead white, zinc white (retouching); ribbon: smalt, ultramarine blue (retouching), cobalt blue (retouching), zinc white (retouching)

77.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth and umber pigments, carbon black, lead white, lead tin yellow

78.title: King Charles I
78.description_physical:
The red lake used to paint the background appears laid down in a non uniform way, probably due to alteration and fading during the years. The raking light images displays a uniformly flat surface, with the exception of the lace on the ruff, thickly applied over an off-white layer, and a retouched area at the top of the object.
The UV image shows the pink UV fluorescence of the background, typical of organic dyes, and the orange colour displayed by lead white used to paint the ruff.

79.title: Anne of Denmark
79.description_physical:
The UV image shows a pink fluorescence corresponding to the pink areas, such as the background and details on the ruff, due to the use of organic dyes. The orange UV colour evident on the white lace and dress is typical of the presence of lead white. A bright yellow fluorescence if documented on the neck pendant, possibly due to the use of modern pigments. 

The blue and green colours appear dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments.

The x-ray image highlights the lead-based materials used to paint white areas, such as the lace and pearls. The flesh tones appears opaque, suggesting that only a small amount of lead white was used.

A few details, such as earrings, neck pendant and white detailing on the dress, appear in high relief in the raking light image, indicating a possible later addition. This is confirmed by MA-XRF maps, as barium is identified in those areas.

80.title: Isaac Oliver
80.description_physical:
The UV image shows the characteristic orange hue of the lead white, used to paint the ruff, cuff and flesh tones. Small retouchings are evident in the blue background, made of a cobalt-based pigment as confirmed by MA-XRF cobalt map.

The x-ray image and lead MA-XRF map show the distribution of this element throughout the sitter's figure. A higher signal belonging to the upper portion of the chest and proper right shoulder may indicate a previous shape of the figure, then altered to what is visible nowadays.

The doublet is made of carbon black mostly, whereas the cape contains bone black.

81.title: Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex
81.description_physical:
The dark background is not usually painted by Isaac Oliver; the mixture of blue and black pigments is also not identified so far in other objects.

The UV image shows retouchings in the background and fleshtones, which appear brighter under UV light because made of zinc white. The orange UV fluorescence of the collar indicates the use of lead white.

X-rays highlight the areas painted with lead, which appear white, such as the collar and eyes; the flesh tones contain only a small amount of lead white, as they appear dark.

83.title: Queen Elizabeth I ('Elizabeth I and the Three Goddesses')
83.description_physical:
Three figures (Queen Elizabeth, Athena and Cupid) show a higher amount of calcium in their faces in comparison to the other ones, where lead white is the predominant pigment.

The miniature seem in a good state of preservation under raking light. The infrared image shows some colour losses in the blue background, which appear white due to the parchment showing through. Blue and green areas appear dark under IR radiation, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments.
The UV image highlights the colour losses in the blue background and through the foliage, and at the left side as well. The white areas showing an orange UV fluorescence are likely painted with lead white, whereas pink paint passages, like Juno's drapery, display a pinkish UV fluorescence typically due to the use of red organic dyes.

The yellow flag around Minerva is painted with different pigments, and differences between the upper and lower portions are evident in the UV and X-ray images. It is unclear if it is a pentimento.

83.pigments_costume: Blue: azurite; pink: red organic dye; white: lead white, chalk; yellow: lead tin yellow, lead white, chalk; black: bone black; red: earth pigment; vermilion; grey: smalt.

84.title: Anne of Denmark
84.description_physical:
Some details in the hair ornaments, brooches and pendant contain brass.
Under UV light, the miniature appears heavily retouched. Areas with a yellow-green UV fluorescence, such as the pearls and portions of the ruff, are retouched with zinc white. Orange parts are lead white retouchings?? 
The red background has a reddish UV fluorescence, characterisc of red lakes. 
Green and blue areas appear dark in the NIR image, suggesting the use of copper-based pigments. The shaded area of the ruff is also dark to the NIR radiation, likely due to the use of carbon black to shade the portion.
The x-ray highlights the use of metals and lead-based pigments (lead white and red lead), which appear bright in the image. The flesh tones are painted with only a small amount of lead white.

85.title: Charles I as a Child, King of England Scotland and Ireland
85.description_physical:
Under UV and raking light, the miniature appears in a good state of preservation, and no retouchings are evident. The red background and pink lips show a reddish UV fluorescence, indicating the use of red lakes. White areas that appear orange under UV, such as the collar and eyes, are painted with lead white.
Blue and green areas appear dark in the NIR region, suggesting the presence of copper-based pigments. The shading part of the collar also appears dark, indicating the use of carbon black to make this area grey.
The x-ray image highlights the use of heavy elements, such as lead, that appear brighter. A round shape painted with an heavy element, identified with XRF as mercury, is also evident at the centre of the miniature, but it belongs to the playing card used as support. The flesh tones and hair appear painted with a very small amount of lead-based pigments.
The vermilion distribution linked to the playing card could suggest that a figure card was used.

86.title: Richard Sackville, 3rd Earl of Dorset (1589-1624)
86.description_physical:
Colour losses are evident around the top border, evident in the raking light and NIR images. Possible losses or retouchings are documented by UV in the flesh tones, which appear bright white and likely due to the fluorescence of the parchment underneath. The orange UV fluorescence documented in portions of the flesh tones and the lace on the collar is due to the use of lead white.
The x-ray image shows the distribution of heavy elements, such as lead, in the background and on the white lace, whereas the flesh tones seem to contain only a small amount of lead-based pigments.

87.title: An unknown child
87.description_physical:
The UV image shows the typical orange hue of the fluorescence coming from lead white, for instance evident on the lace of the headdress and white detailing of the dress. The pink UV fluorescence of the background suggests the use of organic dyes, likely also employed for the orange sash.
The x-ray image shows the lead-based detailing of the lace and dress, but almost no lead white seems to be applied for the flesh tones.

89.title: A gentleman, called Sir Philip Sidney (1554-1588)
89.sitter_text: A gentleman, called Sir Philip Sidney
89.description_physical:
The white collar, with the exception of the outer lace trim, is predominantly painted with calomel (appearing reddish in the UV image), which has darkened in places. The consistent presence of sulphur could hail from the vitriol used to make calomel. The outer lace trim is painted with lead white only, while a small addition of lead white is present in the solid part of the collar. A lipidic binder was also identified.
The purple doublet contains a carbon-based black applied as a brushy underlayer (dark pattern in NIR image), while a red organic dye, which gives a pinkish UV fluorescence, and other pigments are used to achieve the purple tone.
89.pigments_costume: Purple doublet: red organic dye, indigo, lead white, carbon black(?), barium white (retouch); collar: lead white, calomel/mercury white, zinc white (retouch)

89.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, copper-based pigment, carbon black

105.title: A party in the open air. Allegory on conjugal love
105.description_physical:
The flesh tones contain a mixture of lead white and red lead; on the male sitters' flesh tones investigated, there is an addition of hematite and likely pararealgar.
A number of green pigments have been identified, often mixed together to create the foliage of trees. Brochantite is found in the bluish areas of foliage, landscape, and some clothing, while malachite has been used as a bright green on foliage and landscape. A mixture of azurite and indigo is found in green grass and bushes, likely with the addition of a yellow component (not earth pigments).
A lipid binder, associated with egg yolk or oil, is identified by FTIR in passages with black, red (vermilion) and copper-based green pigments. Calcium oxalate was also identified on several areas.
105.pigments_background: Blue background: azurite; grey landscape: smalt; green leaves: brochantite, azurite, malachite, indigo, chrome green (retouching); yellow foliage: lead-tin yellow, lead white, massicot; red foliage: vermilion; brown trunks: earth pigments, bone black
105.pigments_costume: Black costumes: bone black; white ruffs: lead white; orange costumes: red lead; pink costumes: red organic dyes; lilac/cangiante dress: red organic dye, azurite; yellow costumes: lead-tin yellow, yellow earth; blue parts: azurite, brochantite
105.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead, hematite, pararealgar

106.description_physical: The UV images shows extensive retouching in the flesh tones, appearing bright due to the presence of zinc white. The different response in the NIR image of the blue area of the breastplate indicates that the original azurite (appearing dark in the NIR region) has been lost and retouched with another blue pigment that do not contain copper (therefore, appearing transparent to the IR radiation).

107.title: Anne of Denmark (1574-1619)
107.description_physical:
White highlights on top of the blue and the white hair veil are painted using calomel (a mercury white). These areas appear white, while in contrast, the lead white used to paint flesh tones and pearls appears darkened. 
The UV image shows a large retouching on the flesh tones, appearing bright due to the use of zinc white, and other localised ones on the background and pearls. The pale orange UV fluorescence evident on the embroidered clothing, the pearls and the veil, is due to the use of lead white. The pinkish UV fluorescence on the red toga and lips is due to the red organic dyes, while the red UV fluorescence on the blue garment is due to the calomel.
The blue garment is made of azurite, although ultramarine blue is also likely present: the NIR image shows a moderate shade of grey in contrast to the very dark typically detected from azurite alone.
107.pigments_background: Bone black, indigo, earth pigments, lead white
107.pigments_costume: Red toga: red lake; blue garb: azurite, ultramarine(?), calomel/mercury white
107.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?), zinc white (retouching)
107.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, bone black, lead-based pigment

112.title: Frederick, Count Palatine, later Frederick V, King of Bohemia (1596-1632)
112.sitter_text: Frederick, Count Palatine, later Frederick V, King of Bohemia
112.description_physical:
Retouching is evident in the UV image on the forehead and on a localised area on the ribbon. The mauve doublet produces a purple UV fluorescence that may be due to the presence of organic dyes. The orange pale UV fluorescence of the lace corresponds to the use of lead white. 
Unusually, smalt is used to shade the blue background along the side edges and to paint the more intensely blue strokes of the ribbon. It is unclear if it is retouching.

120.title: Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex (1566-1601)
120.description_physical: The unusual grey background contains a mixture of indigo, a red organic dye, and lead white. The UV image shows a purplish fluorescence on this area, likely associated with the use of organic dyes. Localised retouching is evident due to the bright fluorescence colour of the zinc white. The x-ray image shows the distribution of the lead white, which appears opaque, on the background.
120.pigments_background: Indigo, red organic dye, lead white
120.pigments_costume: Black doublet: bone black, lead white; white collar: lead white, indigo (shading); blue ribbon: ultramarine, cobalt-based blue (retouching), zinc white (retouching), barium white (retouching)
120.pigments_flesh_tones_and_lips: Flesh tones: lead white, red lead(?); lips: red lead, red lake
120.pigments_hair_and_beard: Earth pigments, bone black, lead white, chalk

121.title: Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales (1594-1612)
121.description_physical: The blue ribbon is painted with both ultramarine blue and azurite, one of these pigments has likely been adulterated with a small amount of smalt. The distribution of bone black in the background is evident in the NIR image, appearing dark. The pinkish UV fluorescence in the background and lips is linked to the use of red organic dyes, while the pale orange UV colour of the collar depends on the use of lead white.
121.pigments_costume: Brown arrmour: earth pigments, chalk, lead-based pigment; grey armour: lead white, carbon black; white ruff: lead white; blue ribbon: azurite, ultramarine, cobalt blue (retouching), cerulean blue (retouching), zinc white (retouching)
